questions.text: A patient with asthma developed nasal polyps and sinusitis. Which of the following drugs is the patient sensitive to?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aspirin Samter’s triad or AERD (Aspirin Exacerbated Respiratory Disease) is a respiratory condition consisting of 3 factors: Asthma, nasal polyp, and aspirin sensitivity.

Highyeild:

AERD (Aspirin Exacerbated Respiratory Disease) is caused by NSAIDs like ibuprofen, naloxone. Samters triad- polyp/sinusitis, asthma, aspirin sensitivity Young syndrome – polyp/ sinusitis, bronchiectasis, azoospermia/ infertility Kartagener’s syndrome – polyp/ sinusitis, bronchiectasis, situs inversus/ dextrocardia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A and C - Gentamycin and cetirizine do not cause AERD.

questions.text: A patient started vigorous coughing and was visibly seen choking during dinner due to obstruction of the airway by the food particles accidentally. What will be your next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Heimlich Maneuver Heimlich maneuver is done when patient is conscious and choking, hence option B is the best choice for this case.

Highyeild:

Performing Heimlich maneuver involves a rescuer standing behind a patient and using their hands to exert pressure on the bottom of the diaphragm. This compresses the lungs and exerts pressure on any object lodged in the trachea , hopefully expelling it. The pressure amounts to an artificially induced cough . To assist a larger person, more force may be needed.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - If the victim cannot receive pressures on the abdomen (for example, in case of pregnancy or excessive obesity), chest thrusts are advised instead.These are applied on the lower half of the chest bone, but not in the very endpoint (which is the xiphoid process and could be broken). Option C - Endoscopy is done in case patient is unconscious. Option D - wait and watch is never done.

Extraedge:

Cricothyrotomy or emergency tracheostomy should be done if Heimlich manoeuvre fails. Once acute respiratory emergency is over, foreign body can be removed by direct laryngoscopy or by laryngofissure, if impacted.

questions.text: An 18 years old male presented with chief complaint of recurrent epistaxis with nasal blockage. On nasal endoscopy, a polypoidal mass is seen going from nose to nasopharynx, completely occupying the posterior choana as seen in the image. Most likely diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma From the above history and examination findings diagnosis of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is made.

Highyeild:

JUVENILE NASOPHARYNGEAL ANGIOFIBROMA Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma’s are a rare benign, but locally aggressive, vascular tumors that occurs almost exclusively in young men. The presentation is typical with painless, progressive unilateral obstructive symptoms with or without epistaxis , rhinorrhea and chronic otomastoiditis due to obstruction of the Eustachian tube . Patients may present with life-threatening epistaxis. On examination, it may be seen as a pale reddish-blue mass. It is, as the name suggests, very vascular and a biopsy can sometimes be fatal. Histopathology reveals a fibrocellular stroma with spindle cells and haphazard arrangement of collagen interspersed with an irregular vascular pattern. On imaging, they present as a vividly enhancing soft-tissue masses centered on the sphenopalatine foramen . Given its vascularity, prominent flow voids are seen on MRI leading to a salt and pepper appearance.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Nasal polyps are Non-neoplastic masses of oedematous nasal or sinus mucosa. Option B: Rhinosporidiosis is a rare, infectious, chronic granulomatous disease of the mucous membranes caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, an endo sporulating microorganism. It usually manifests as vascular friable polyps that arise from the nasal mucosa or external structures of the eye. This appearance results from sporangia, which are visible as gray or yellow spots in the vascular polypoid masses. Option C: An inverted papilloma, also known as transitional papilloma, Ringertz tumour or Schneiderian papilloma, is a type of tumor in which surface epithelial cells grow downward into the underlying supportive tissue. Clinical features depend mainly on the anatomic site of its occurrence, and unilateral nasal obstruction represents the most frequent symptom.It tends to present in the fifth to seventh decades of life

Extraedge:

TYPES: Type I includes lesions fundamentally localized to the nasal cavity, paranasal sinus, nasopharynx, or pterygopalatine fossa. Type II is a JNA extending into the infratemporal fossa, buccal region, or orbital cavity with anterior and/or minimal middle cranial fossa extension but intact dura mater. Type III is a calabash-like massive tumor lobe in the middle cranial fossa.

questions.text: A child presents with fullness in the ear and mild hearing loss. The endoscopic image of the tympanic membrane is given below. Identify the clinical condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Serous Otitis Media Acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM) is an acute, suppurative infectious process marked by the presence of infected middle ear fluid and inflammation of the mucosa lining the middle ear space. The infection is most frequently precipitated by impaired function of the Eustachian tube, resulting in the retention and suppuration of retained secretions. ASOM may also be associated with purulent otorrhea if there is a ruptured tympanic membrane. ASOM usually responds promptly to antimicrobial therapy. It is often characterized by hearing loss and a sense aural fullness. Otoscopy reveals the presence of middle ear fluid without a bulging tympanic membrane or evidence of active infection. The tympanic membrane is intact and may or may not be retracted, depending on the chronicity of the effusion.

Highyeild:

STAGES OF ACUTE OTITIS MEDIA Stage 1: HYPEREMIA Stage 2: EXUDATION Stage 3: SUPPURATION Stage 4: COALESCENCE Stage 5: COMPLICATIONS

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B: Bullous myringitis (BM) is a relatively common infectious condition characterized by bullae or vesicles on the tympanic membrane (TM), without affecting the contents of the external or middle ear. If the middle ear becomes involved, this would be consistent with acute otitis media (AOM) and not merely bullous myringitis. As the tympanic membrane is well innervated, moderate to severe pain is a common expected manifestation. Physical findings may be similar to those of acute otitis media, including erythema and thickening of the tympanic membrane, attenuated or absent light reflex, and decrease membrane mobility. Bloody otorrhea can occur when a bulla ruptures and is referred to as bullous hemorrhagic myringitis. The rupturing of bulla often results in a concomitant reduction of pain. The vesicles occur between the outer epithelium and the lamina propria of the tympanic membrane Option C: Pneumotympanum may occur following temporal bone fracture and does not present with the typical picture of suppuration. Option D: Tuberculous otitis media (TOM) is a rare cause of chronic suppurative infection of the middle ear and mastoid. Patients typically have a chronic tympanic membrane perforation and ear drainage associated with progressive and profound hearing loss. The correct diagnosis starts with consideration of the disease in a patient with a chronic middle ear infection that is unresponsive to routine therapy. Classic presentations of tuberculous otitis media include painless otorrhea, multiple perforations of the tympanic membrane, beefy red granulation tissue, hearing loss, preauricular adenopathy, and an ipsilateral facial nerve palsy. OM should be strongly considered in patients with known or suspected tuberculosis and a chronic ear infection; however, the lack of evidence of tuberculosis elsewhere does not exclude the possibility of TOM. Appropriate evaluation for TOM includes a chest film, purified protein derivative (PPD) skin testing, and smears or cultures of otic secretions for mycobacteria.

questions.text: A patient with high frequency hearing loss due to damage to the basilar membrane and structure closest to it. Which of the following structure is most likely to be injured?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oval Window Figure below shows Tuning curves for primary afferents at different locations on the cochlea . Afferents from inner hair cells near the apex show a maximum sensitivity (lowest threshold) to sounds with low frequencies (black curve). Primary afferents from inner hair cells near the base show maximum sensitivity to higher frequencies (curve on far right) . Cells in between show intermediate behavior (middle two curves) . The sensitivity falls off sharply at higher frequencies, but lower frequencies can still excite the afferents off their maximum sensitivity. Thus, in a scenario where there i s high frequency hearing loss due to damage to the basilar membrane and structure closest to it, the most probable structure injured along with basilar membrane is the oval window.

Highyeild:

The middle ear ossicles transmit sound-related vibratory energy from the eardrum to the oval window, where vibrations are set up in the fluid media of the cochlea. The organ of Corti, located on the upper surface of the basilar membrane of the cochlea, contains specialized hair cells that act as the neural transducers in this system. The basilar membrane is a stiff structural element within the cochlea of the inner ear which separates two liquid-filled tubes that run along the coil of the cochlea, the scala media and the scala tympani. Oscillations of the basilar membrane produce an activating shearing force on the cilia of the hair cells.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - helicotrema - The helicotrema is the most apical portion of the cochlea and is defined as the region where the scala tympani and scala vestibuli meet at the end of the BM. Option C. Stria Vascularis - The stria vascularis, composed of marginal, intermediate, and basal cells, is responsible for maintaining the ion composition of the endolymph and producing an endocochlear potential (EP) in the scala media Option D. Semi Circular Canal - Located in the inner ear, the semicircular canals are three very small tubes whose primary job is to regulate balance and sense head position. They're considered part of the vestibular apparatus of the body.

Extraedge:

The mechanical properties of the basilar membrane are such that high-frequency sounds cause oscillations at the base of the membrane, near the oval window, whereas low-frequency sounds cause oscillations at the apex. This imparts tonotopic organization to the hair cells along the organ of Corti. Cells at the apex encode low-frequency sounds, and cells at the base, high-frequency sounds.

questions.text: A 65 yrs old patient presented with gradually increasing growth beside the nose near the medial canthus with ulcerated nodule on tip of nose measuring 0.7cm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

BCC Image shows palisading arrangement of peripheral cells which is characteristic feature of BCC.

Highyeild:

BASAL CELL CARCINOMA OF NOSE This is the most common malignant tumour involving skin of nose . Equally affecting males and females in the age group of 40–60 years. Common sites on the nose are the tip and the ala. It may present as a cyst or papulo-pearly nodule or an ulcer with rolled edges. It is very slow growing and remains confined to the skin for a long time. Underlying cartilage or bone may get invaded. Nodal metastases are extremely rare. Basal cell carcinoma of the nose

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B - SCC shows keratin pearls. Option C - Melanoma shows melanin granules. Option D - Adeno Carcinoma - Cancer that forms in the glandular tissue, which lines certain internal organs and makes and releases substances in the body, such as mucus, digestive juices, and other fluids.

Extraedge:

Treatment depends on the size, location and depth of the tumour. Early lesion can be cured by cryosurgery, irradiation or surgical excision with 3–5 mm of healthy skin around the palpable borders of the tumour. Lesions which are recurrent, extensive or with involvement of cartilage or bone are excised and the surgical defect closed by local or distant flaps.

questions.text: A diabetic person, who recovered from COVID 2 months back, now developed severe hemifacial pain predominantly in the jaw and one of the teeth has become loose. Next step in management will be?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

MRI Brain Mucormycosis is a common diagnosis in post covid-immune compromised state. Currently, MRI with gadolinium contrast is the investigation of choice in rhino orbital cerebral mucormycosis.

Highyeild:

MUCORMYCOSIS It most commonly infects the nose , sinuses , eye , and brain resulting in a runny nose , one-sided facial swelling and pain, headache , fever , blurred vision , bulging or displacement of the eye (proptosis), and tissue death . Risk factors include diabetes with persistently high blood sugar levels or diabetic ketoacidosis , low white cells , cancer , organ transplant , iron overload , kidney problems , long-term steroids or use of immunosuppressants , and to a lesser extent in HIV/AIDS . Currently, MRI with gadolinium contrast is the investigation of choice in rhino orbital cerebral mucormycosis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A and B - HbA1c and S. ferritin does not play a role in diagnosing Mucor mycosis. Option D - Nasal Swab can be used to detect Mucor but it does not tell us the extent of infection. Hence MRI is the best choice to diagnose as well as know the spread of Mucor.

Extraedge:

ALSO NOTE: To confirm the diagnosis, biopsy samples can be cultured. Culture from biopsy samples does not always give a result as the organism is very fragile. The appearances can vary but generally show wide, ribbon-like filaments that generally do not have septa and that—unlike in aspergillosis—branch at right angles , which may be seen to be invading blood vessels .

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented with rhinitis and facial swelling. An intranasal biopsy revealed the presence of broad-based aseptate hyphae with branching at right angle. Evidence of vascular invasion was present. What will be the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Amphotericin B Given case scenario is a classic case of Mucormycosis and thus, the best possible management would be to give Amphotericin B in this case.

Highyeild:

Mucormycosis is an aggressive, angioinvasive fungal infection, acquired primarily vial inhalation of environmental sporangiospores (3-11micron) in immunocompromised hosts or direct entry during trauma, and affects these hosts with severe metabolic conditions. Rhino-orbit cerebral mucormycosis (ROCM): Nasal stuffiness, foul smell, epistaxis, nasal discharge, unilateral facial oedema, diplopia, proptosis, pain and redness around eyes and/or nose, loss of vision, restriction of eye movements, palatal or palpebral fistula, blackish discoloration over bridge of nose/palate, prolonged Fever, headache, toothache, loosening of teeth, jaw involvement, altered mental status Cutaneous and soft tissue Mucormycosis: Erythema, induration, then black eschar at trauma/puncture site, muscle pain with deeper involvement Pulmonary mucormycosis: Refractory fever on broad-spectrum antibiotics, non-productive cough, progressive dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain Gastrointestinal Mucormycosis: Fever, bleeding per anus, mass like lesions, then perforation of gut Mucormycosis of bones and joints Local pain and tenderness, cellulitis, fever is rare Disseminated Mucormycosis: Symptoms vary as per site of involvement, mostly associated with pneumonia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Fluconazole is used for the treatment of candidiasis and cryptococcosis. Option C: Ketoconazole is used for both dermatophytosis and deep mycosis, but it has been replaced by Itraconazole. Option D: Griseofulvin is used for dermatophytosis. It is effective against the mycotic disease of the skin, hair, and nails due to Microsporum, Trichophyton, and Epidermophyton.

Extraedge:

Amphotericin B administration and monitoring protocol Drugs Recommended Dose Duration Inj Amphotericin B Deoxycholate (C- AmB) 1.0-1.5 mg/kg/day 14 to 21 days depending on severity/till clinical resolution and radiological stabilization; after 14days of therapy, shift to oral Posaconazole if clinically stable. Inj Liposomal amphotericin B (LAMB): 5-10mg/kg/day Inj Amphotericin B lipid complex (ABLC) 5mg/kg/day

questions.text: A patient presented with angle of mouth deviation to right, drooling of saliva inability to blow, unable to close left eye. Which of the following nerve is involved in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

7th Nerve Palsy Facial nerve palsy: loss of forehead and brow movement, drooping of eyelid, deviation of angle of mouth.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A - 9th nerve palsy symptoms/signs: Dysphagia, Impaired gustation over the posterior third of the tongue and palate. Reduced sensation over the posterior third of the tongue, palate, and pharynx. OPTION B- Trigeminal nerve palsy: Episodes of severe, shooting or jabbing pain that may feel like an electric shock, Spontaneous attacks of pain or attacks triggered by things such as touching the face, chewing, speaking or brushing teeth, Pain that occurs with facial spasms. OPTION C- 3rd nerve palsy: Ocular movements are affected
